{{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=November 2016}} {{More footnotes|date=November 2009}}}}
A '''recording contract''' (commonly called a '''record contract''' or '''record deal''') is a legal agreement between a [[record label]] and a [[recording artist]] (or group), where the artist makes a record (or series of records) for the label to sell and promote. Artists under contract are normally only allowed to record for that label exclusively; guest appearances on other artists' records will carry a notice "By courtesy of (the name of the label)", and that label may receive a percentage of sales.
==Copyrights, payment and royalties== Labels typically own the [[copyright]] in the records their artists make, and also the [[master recording|master copies]] of those records. An exception is when a label makes a [[distribution deal]] with an artist; in this case, the artist, their manager, or another party may own the copyright (and masters), while the record is [[license]]d exclusively to the label for a set period of time. [[Promotion (marketing)|Promotion]] is a key factor in the success of a record, and is largely the label's responsibility, as is proper [[distribution (business)|distribution]] of records.
While initial recording deals usually yield a smaller percentage of [[royalties]] to the artists, subsequent (or renegotiated) deals can result in much greater profit, or profit potential. A few acts, such as [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]], [[Michael Jackson]], [[R.E.M.]], [[U2]], and [[Janet Jackson]], among others, have signed multimillion-dollar deals. [[Whitney Houston]] signed a $100 million deal with [[Bertelsmann Music Group|BMG]] to deliver just six albums, the largest recording deal at the time. [[Robbie Williams]] signed an £80m (US$125m) contract with [[EMI]].<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/uk/2002/oct/03/arts.artsnews | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Fiachra | last=Gibbons | title=Robbie Williams signs £80m deal | date=2002-10-03}}</ref> For many other artists, though, for the millions to become [[tangible]], hit albums meeting or exceeding their previous sales figures must follow. Recording contracts may include opt-out clauses for the label in the event an act's popularity dips or the act releases non-hit albums under the deal. For instance, [[Mariah Carey]] was dropped by [[Virgin Records]] and her $80 million recording deal cancelled after her first album released by the label sold poorly.<ref name="Mayer">{{cite news|url=http://www.cbc.ca/arts/music/carey.html|title=Carey On|work=''[[CBC.ca]]''|publisher=CBC|accessdate=2011-02-24|date=2005-12-13}}</ref>
Record companies put forth huge sums of money to produce, release, and promote an album. Recording time, manufacturing, packaging, photos, distribution, marketing, and music videos are just some of the areas where the label must spend money on an act it has signed. The label usually absorbs these expenses, but in some artists contracts, some of this money may be due back to the label, unless otherwise worded. Advances (upfront money that is paid directly to a recording artist) are normally always owed back to the label. Once (and if) the advance has been paid back from record sales, the artist then begins to see royalty payments for additional sales. Advancing an act money is a risk the label endures as it does not know how well the act's album will sell. [[Capitol Records]] suspended [[Linda Ronstadt]]'s contract in the early 1970s, as Capitol had spent more money on Ronstadt then it had yielded. She continued to tour partly to pay Capitol back for her 1960s deal, and a string of hits in the mid-1970s allowed her to finally clear the debt. Record companies expect to make a profit, and little concern themselves with a given performer's lack of business or financial savvy, as artists such as [[George Michael]] have discovered. "Walking out" on a deal is very difficult or nearly impossible, as is attempting to strike a new deal without completing an old one. [[Donna Summer]] signed a new deal with [[Geffen Records]] in 1980, and released an album on Geffen. She was then told by her previous label, [[Polygram Records]], that she owed them another album, per her agreement. She recorded and delivered [[She Works Hard for the Money (album)|an album]] to Polygram that the label released, and it became a hit. Summer then went back to recording for Geffen Records for [[Cats Without Claws|her next project]]. [[The Mamas & the Papas]] were forced into a reunion, years after their 1968 breakup, by the letter of their [[Dunhill Records]] contract, which required one more album to be completed -which became 1971's ''[[People Like Us (The Mamas and the Papas album)|People Like Us]]''.
Record companies will generally increase royalty rates or give artistic freedom to get acts to re-sign contracts with them once the original deal has been fulfilled. Established acts may otherwise go where they see better opportunity. During 1980, [[Diana Ross]] released her album ''[[Diana (album)|diana]]'', which fulfilled her contract with [[Motown Records]]. The album spawned three US hits (a #1 and two top tens) and sold 10 million copies worldwide. Ross, however, felt she was never fairly compensated by Motown for her work with [[The Supremes]] or her solo releases. When [[RCA Records]] offered her $20 million to sign with them, Ross gave Motown the chance to match the deal, or at least offer something almost comparable. Motown, believing Ross's solo career was too up-and-down, and not seeing any reason to now compensate her for her earlier Supremes work, offered $3 million. Split with the decision to remain with the label that made her famous, or sign a deal with a company that was willing to pay her what she felt she was worth, she ultimately signed with RCA. That $20 million deal was the biggest recording contract at the time. She had signed with RCA for North America only, she signed a separate longterm contract with Capitol/EMI for international territories. That contractual amount was never officially released. However, it is believed to be as much as $20 more million and she has remained currently signed with them for over 30 years and has produced many more successful recordings internationally including her multi-platinum 1991 release, ''[[The Force Behind the Power]]'' and an even greater success with a greatest hits compilation, ''[[One Woman: The Ultimate Collection]]'' that sold over 1.5 million in the United Kingdom alone, spending several weeks at #1.
There are plenty examples of recording contracts available in music business guides, legal texts and also online.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.musiclawcontracts.com/recording-contract/ |title=Exclusive Recording Contract Template |website=Musiclawcontracts.com |date=2016-03-05 |accessdate=2016-11-21}}</ref>
==Termination== When recordings go out of print, this typically happens because either the label has decided that continuing to sell (or distribute) the record will not be profitable, or the licensing agreement with the artist has expired. (Labels may also stop distribution as a punitive measure, if an artist fails to comply with their contract, or as a strategic measure if negotiations for a new one prove difficult.) Record labels can also become [[bankruptcy|bankrupt]] like any business, and their masters and copyrights sold or traded as part of their assets. (Occasionally these are purchased by the artists themselves.)
Recording artists signed to a failed label can find themselves in limbo, unable to record for anyone but a company that is out of business (and thus cannot sell or distribute their records), and with their existing works unavailable for sale. When one label "buys out" another (or a label is purchased by an outside party), any existing copyrights and contracts held (and masters, if owned by the label) normally go with the sale. This often benefits recording artists, but not always.
Distribution deals are often renewed, but occasionally the label and the copyright owner cannot come to terms for a renewal. The reason is usually that one party expects too much money, or too large a percentage of profits, to suit the other.
==See also== * [[Distribution deal]] * [[360 deal]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Bibliography== *''A Band's Guide to Getting a Record Deal'' by Will Ashurst; {{ISBN|1-86074-243-2}}
{{Music industry}}

{{Infobox religious building | building_name = Safa Mosque | infobox_width = | image = | caption = | map_type = Iran | map_size = 275 | location = [[Isfahan]], [[Iran]] | coordinates = {{coord|32.674532|51.683967|display=inline,title}} | religious_affiliation = [[Shia Islam]] | rite = | region = | state = | province = Isfahan | territory = | prefecture = | sector = | district = | cercle = | municipality = Isfahan | consecration_year = | status = | functional_status = | heritage_designation = | leadership = | website = | architecture = yes | architect = | architecture_type = [[Mosque]] | architecture_style = [[Isfahani style|Isfahani]] | general_contractor = | facade_direction = | groundbreaking = | year_completed = | construction_cost = | specifications = | capacity = | length = | width = | width_nave = | height_max = | dome_quantity = | dome_height_outer = | dome_height_inner = | dome_dia_outer = | dome_dia_inner = | minaret_quantity = | minaret_height = | spire_quantity = | spire_height = | materials = | nrhp = | added = | refnum = | designated = }} The '''Safa Mosque''' is a historical [[mosque]] in [[Isfahan]], [[Iran]]. {{EngvarB|date=December 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Sarah Dollard | birth_date = 21 January 1980 | nationality = Australian | occupation = Screenwriter, script editor | yearsactive = 2004–present | known_for = ''[[Neighbours]]'', ''Cara Fi'', ''Doctor Who'' }} '''Sarah Dollard''' (born 21 January 1980) is an Australian television screenwriter, living and working in the United Kingdom. She made her start in writing for television on the long-running Australian soap opera ''[[Neighbours]]'', before moving to the UK in 2008. She created and wrote the Welsh [[romantic comedy]] series ''Cara Fi'' (Love Me), which debuted on [[S4C]] in 2014.<ref name="Wales Online">{{cite news | url= http://www.walesonline.co.uk/whats-on/arts-culture-news/sport-drama-documentaries-baking-heart-7713997 | title= Sport, drama, documentaries and baking at the heart of S4C's autumn schedule | work= Wales Online | date=3 September 2014 | accessdate=3 December 2014 | author=Owens, David}}</ref> ==Career== ===''Neighbours''=== Dollard worked on ''[[Neighbours]]'' for four years, as a storyliner, a script editor, a story editor, and a writer of over thirty episodes.<ref name="Post">{{cite news | url= http://www.dailypost.co.uk/news/local-news/win-romantic-break-inspired-new-8041768 | title= Win a romantic break inspired by new S4C series Cara Fi | work= Daily Post | date=3 November 2014 | accessdate=21 November 2014 | author=Jones, Wendy}}</ref> Before leaving Australia, she also worked in script development for popular children's television series ''[[The Saddle Club]]'', and in development on other children's shows with the [[Australian Children's Television Foundation]]. ===Move to the UK=== After moving to the UK, Dollard began working in the script departments of British [[fantasy]] and [[sci-fi|science fiction]] TV shows. She worked on season two of [[BBC One]] [[fantasy]]-[[Adventure film|adventure]] series ''[[Merlin (TV series)|Merlin]]'', before moving on to ''[[Primeval (TV series)|Primeval]]'' in 2010, where she script-edited seasons four and five of the sci-fi series and wrote all five episodes of the ''[[Primeval (TV series)|Primeval]]'' web-series that introduced season four.<ref name="Primeval">{{cite news | url= http://www.blastr.com/2010/12/5_webisodes_you_should_watch_before_seeing_primeval_season_4.php | title= 5 webisodes you should watch before seeing Primeval season 4 | work= Blastr | date=29 December 2010 | accessdate=3 December 2014 | author=Caron, Nathalie}}</ref><ref name="Exclusive episodes">{{cite web|url=http://www.itv.com/drama/primeval/exclusiveepisodes/|title=Exclusive episodes|publisher=ITV|date=23 December 2010|accessdate=2 January 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101220225309/http://www.itv.com/drama/primeval/exclusiveepisodes/|archivedate=20 December 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
Dollard wrote the fifth episode of the fifth season of [[Toby Whithouse]]'s popular [[BBC Three]] series ''[[Being Human (UK TV series)|Being Human]]'',<ref name="SciFiNow">{{cite news | url= http://www.scifinow.co.uk/reviews/being-human-s05e05-no-care-all-responsibility-episode-review/ | title= Being Human S05E05 'No Care, All Responsibility' Episode Review | work= SciFiNow | date=5 March 2013 | accessdate=3 December 2014 | author=Hatfull, Jonathan}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/episode/vkh28/being-human--series-5---5-no-care-all-responsibility |title=Being Human | Series 5 – 5. No Care, All Responsibility |work=Radio Times |accessdate=1 March 2013}}</ref> featuring guest star [[Kathryn Prescott]], of ''[[Skins (UK TV series)|Skins]]'' fame. [[Digital Spy]] called the episode, titled ''No Care, All Responsibility'', "the latest in a string of knockout episodes – sweet and chilling in equal measure". Dollard also penned the [[webisode]]s that accompanied ''[[Being Human (UK TV series)|Being Human]]'' season five,<ref name="BBC3">{{cite web | url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/beinghuman/entries/9613cec2-e8e9-3e1d-a93e-e35dbdb3364f | title= Alex's Kicked The Bucket List | work=BBC Three Blog | date=5 February 2013 | accessdate=3 December 2014}}</ref> focusing on the character of [[Alex Millar (Being Human)|Alex Millar]], played by [[Kate Bracken]].
She wrote episode three of [[BBC]] [[Spy fiction|spy]] [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]] ''[[The Game (UK TV series)|The Game]]'', and co-wrote episode five with series creator [[Toby Whithouse]].<ref name="BBC">{{cite news | url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/mediacentre/worldwide/2014/bbc-america-the-game | title=The Game Begins November 5 at 10:00 pm as part of BBC America's Dramaville | work=BBC Media Centre | date=17 September 2014 | accessdate=20 November 2014}}</ref> ===''Cara Fi'' and beyond=== Dollard created and wrote her own [[romantic comedy|rom-com]] series ''[[Cara Fi]]'' (Love Me) with Touchpaper Television, for the Welsh broadcaster [[S4C]].<ref name="Post" /> The eight episode series focuses on a sleepy seaside village in [[Wales]] that runs out of women, so the locals advertise their single men on the side of milk cartons leaving the dairy. Each episode focuses on a new woman arriving in the village to be set up with a local man.<ref name="Milford">{{cite news | url=http://www.milfordmercury.co.uk/news/11121622.Little_Haven_is_star_of_new_S4C | title= Little Haven is star of new S4C show | work= Milford and West Wales Mercury | date=2 April 2014 | accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref><ref name="Tenby">{{cite news | url=http://www.tenby-today.co.uk/news.cfm?id=14077 | title= Brand new romantic comedy drama on S4C | work= Tenby Observer | date=7 November 2014 | accessdate=9 November 2014}}</ref> The show debuted in November 2014 on [[S4C]], and was subsequently on the [[BBC iPlayer]].<ref name="Telegraph">{{cite news | url=http://www.westerntelegraph.co.uk/news/11587408.Fall_in_love_with_Little_Haven_in_new_S4C_rom_com/ | title= Fall in love with Little Haven in new S4C rom-com | work=Western Telegraph | date=9 November 2014 | accessdate=22 November 2014}}</ref>
In 2015, she wrote the tenth episode of the [[Doctor Who (series 9)|ninth series]] of ''[[Doctor Who]]'', titled "[[Face the Raven]]",.<ref name="bbc who"/><ref>{{cite web|title=BREAKING NEWS! Here are the titles for every episode in the new series! |url=https://twitter.com/bbcdoctorwho/status/643426490084929537|website=Twitter|accessdate=14 September 2015|date=14 September 2015}}{{Primary source inline|date=December 2017}}</ref> She also wrote an episode of the UK-US co-produced comedy-drama ''[[You, Me and the Apocalypse]]'',<ref>{{cite news |last=Trenholm |first=Richard |url= http://www.cnet.com/news/rob-lowe-faces-the-sky-falling-in-you-me-the-apocalypse/ |title=Rob Lowe faces the Sky falling in 'You, Me & The Apocalypse' |publisher=[[CNET]] |date=9 July 2015 }}</ref> and ITV period drama [[The Halcyon]].<ref name="THR">{{cite news | url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/doctor-who-writer-adapting-ya-novel-cuckoo-song-uk-startup-catalyst-952151 | title= Doctor Who Writer Adapting YA Novel 'Cuckoo Song' | work= THR | date=2 December 2016 | accessdate=12 January 2017 | author=Ritman, Alex}}</ref> She returned to write the episode "[[Thin Ice (Doctor Who)|Thin Ice]]" for [[Doctor Who (series 10)|Series 10]] of [[Doctor Who]].<ref name="bbc who">{{cite news | url= http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/doctorwho/entries/a2f29a2b-62bd-4916-a910-eb3077d211eb | title= Joivan Wade Returns as Rigsy in a New Series Episode Written by Sarah Dollard | publisher= BBC | date=10 June 2015 | accessdate=10 June 2015}}</ref>
In December 2016 it was announced that Dollard would adapt YA novel "Cuckoo Song" for television.<ref name="THR"/> Written by [[Frances Hardinge]], the novel was "the first YA book to win the British Fantasy Awards' top prize and was shortlisted for both the Carnegie Medal and the James Herbert Award".<ref name="THR"/>
In 2018, she will write for ''A Discovery of Witches'', a television film series based on the [[A Discovery of Witches (book series)|novel trilogy of the same name]] by [[Deborah Harkness]].<ref name="8 February 2018">{{cite web|last1=Andrew|first1=G.G|title=What We Know About the 'A Discovery of Witches' TV Show So Far|url=https://www.bookbub.com/blog/2018/02/07/a-discovery-of-witches-tv-show-adaptation-details|website=BookBub|accessdate=2 May 2018}}</ref> ==References== {{Reflist|2}}
==External links== *{{IMDb name|2183823}} *[http://www.perfectblend.net/neighbourhood/pro/dollard-sarah.htm Profile] at The Perfect Blend
{{Authority control}}

{{news release|article|date=March 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Space Group Company | logo = | logo_size = | founded = 1999 | hq_location = Oslo, Norway | key_people = [[Gary Bates]], [[Gro Bonesmo]], [[Floire Nathanael Daub]] | industry = Architecture | website = https://www.spacegroup.no }} '''Space Group''' is an architecture office established in 1999 in [[Oslo|Oslo, Norway]] and created by Gary Bates and Gro Bonesmo. Prior to founding Space Group, they worked with [[Office for Metropolitan Architecture|OMA]]/[[Rem Koolhaas]], which they later on collaborated for the Vestbanen project in Oslo.
The firm is also known for leading large master plan development and research. One of their current involvement is for the project "8 million city"/Station City, connecting Oslo to Copenhagen by train.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tu.no/artikler/storselskaper-vil-betale-15-milliarder-for-jernbane-mellom-norge-og-sverige/276182|title=Storselskaper vil betale 15 milliarder for jernbane mellom Norge og Sverige|website=Tu.no|access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref> They were the curator of the Nordic Pavilion at the 14th International Architecture Exhibition at the [[Venice Biennale of Architecture|Venice Biennale]] in 2014.
== Notable work == * Verkstedhallen, [[Aker Brygge]], Oslo (completed 2014) * Aker Brygge Masterplan, Oslo (completed 2014) * Nedregate Cultural District, Oslo (completed 2013)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.archdaily.com/385073/nedregate-culture-district-space-group|title=Nedregate Culture District / Space Group|website=ArchDaily|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref> * Trondheim [[Choice Hotels|Clarion Hotel]] & Congress, Trondheim (completed 2012)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.archdaily.com/337342/clarion-hotel-congress-trondheim-space-group-architects|title=Clarion Hotel & Congress Trondheim / Space Group|website=ArchDaily|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref> * Luftfartstilsynet - Norwegian Civil Aviation HQ, Bodø (completed 2011)<ref name=":02">{{Cite web|url=http://www.archdaily.com/242795/norwegian-civil-aviation-authority-hq-space-group-architects|title=Norwegian Civil Aviation Authority HQ / Space Group Architects|website=ArchDaily|language=en-US|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref> * Blue Moon House SRH, Groningen (completed 2001)<ref>{{Cite book|title=Architecture in the Netherlands 2001>02|last=Hoogewoning|first=Anne|last2=van Toorn|first2=Roemer|last3=Vollaard|first3=Piet|last4=Wortmann|first4=Arthur|publisher=NAi Uitgevers|year=2002|isbn=9789056622534|location=|pages=150}}</ref> * Varner House, Asker (completed 2003)<ref>{{Cite book|title=Project: V-house, architect: Space group|last=Weinstock|first=Michael|publisher=Pax Forlag|year=2011|isbn=9788253033679|location=|pages=}}</ref>
== Main competitions == * 2012 Nye Ruten with Superunion ([[Sandnes|Sandnes, Norway]]) * 2010 Opera And Culture House with Brisac Gonzalez ([[Kristiansand|Kristiansand, Norway]]) * 2008 [[Oslo Central Station]] ([[Oslo, Norway]]) * 2008 Luftfartstilsynet - Norwegian Civil Aviation HQ ([[Bodø|Bodø, Norway]]) * 2002 [[Oslo West Station]] Library & Museum with [[Office for Metropolitan Architecture|OMA]] and [[Rex Architecture P.C.|REX Architecture]] ([[Oslo, Norway]])
== Selected awards == * 2013 Metall 13, Clarion Hotel and Congress Trondheim, Norway<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.metalsupply.no/article/view/116173/metallprisen_2013_til_space_group_arkitekter_for_clarion_trondheim|title=Metallprisen 2013 til Space Group Arkitekter for Clarion Trondheim|website=Metal Supply NO|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref> * 2013 Oslo bys arkitekturpris Nedregate Culture District / Nedregate 5-7, Oslo, Norway<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://arkitektur.no/nedregate-kulturdistrikt?lcid=1033&pid1=230396|title=Nedregate kulturdistrikt {{!}} NAL|last=Anda|first=Per|website=arkitektur.no|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref> * 2012 DNB Eiendomspris Clarion Hotel and Congress Trondheim, Norway<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.mynewsdesk.com/no/clarion-hotel/pressreleases/eiendomsprisen-2012-til-clarion-hotel-congress-trondheim-810724|title=Eiendomsprisen 2012 til Clarion Hotel & Congress Trondheim|website=Mynewsdesk|access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref> * 2012 Houens Fund Diploma Varner House, Asker, Norway<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abcnyheter.no/livet/2012/06/08/153052/norges-flotteste-villa-ligger-i-asker|title=Norges flotteste villa ligger i Asker {{!}} ABC Nyheter|website=www.abcnyheter.no|access-date=2016-03-02}}</ref> * 2005 European Steel Award Varner House, Asker, Norway<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bygg.no/article/11738|title=Stålpris til V-house|website=Bygg.no - Byggeindustrien|language=nb-NO|access-date=2016-03-03}}</ref> * 2005 [[International Architecture Biennal Rotterdam|International Architectural Biennal Rotterdam]], curator Adriaan Geuze – ‘THE FLOOD’ Catamaran City
== Publication == * ''SPACEGROUP, Norway: Untitled 2000-2008 DD30'' Damdi Publishing Company Publishers. 2008. {{ISBN|978-8-99111-137-0}}
== Exhibitions == * 2015 ''Snapshot'' Galleri Rom, Oslo * 2015 ''Forms of Freedom. African Independence and Nordic Models,'' [[National Museum of Art, Architecture and Design|Nasjonalmuseet – Arkitektur, Fehn-paviljongen]] * 2014 ''Forms of Freedom'' curator of Nordic Pavilion, [[Venice Biennale of Architecture|Venice Biennale]] * 2011 ''From Skin to Flesh'' Galeria Eduardo Fernandes, [[São Paulo]], curated by Ricardo de Ostos * 2012 ''Light Houses: On the Nordic Common Ground. Nordic Pavilion'', [[Venice Biennale of Architecture|Venice Biennale]]<ref>{{Cite book|title=Common Ground: 13th International Architecture Exhibition. La Biennale di Venezia|last=Chipperfield|first=David|publisher=Marsilio|year=2012|isbn=9788831713665|location=|pages=236–237}}</ref> * 2004 SPACE GROUP: ''Exposed Experiment Change'', Galleri Rom, Oslo
== References == <references />

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2015}} '''Systems-oriented design''' ('''S.O.D.''') uses [[system thinking]] in order to capture the [[complexity]] of [[system]]s addressed in [[Design|design practice]]. The main mission of S.O.D. is to build the [[designer]]s' own interpretation and implementation of systems thinking. S.O.D. aims at enabling systems thinking to fully benefit from [[design thinking]] and practice, and design thinking and practice to fully benefit from systems thinking. S.O.D. addresses design for human activity systems, and can be applied to any kind of design problem ranging from [[product design]] and [[interaction design]], through [[architecture]] to [[Decision making|decision making processes]] and policy design.
== Background == Design is getting more and more complex for a number of reasons, for example due to [[globalization]], need for [[sustainability]], and the introduction of new [[technology]] and increased use of [[automation]]. Many of the challenges designers meet today can be considered [[wicked problems]].<ref name="Rittel">Rittel, Horst, and Melvin Webber, 1973. "Dilemmas in a General Theory of Planning." Policy Sciences 4: 155-169. {{cite web |url=http://www.metu.edu.tr/~baykan/arch467/Rittel%2BWebber%2BDilemmas.pdf |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-10-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130721100404/http://www.metu.edu.tr/~baykan/arch467/Rittel%2BWebber%2BDilemmas.pdf |archivedate=21 July 2013 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> The characteristics of a wicked problem include among others that there are no definitive formulation of the problem and that the solutions are never true-or-false, but rather better or worse.<ref name="Rittel" /> A traditional problem solving approach is not sufficient in addressing for such design problems. S.O.D. is an approach that addresses the challenges the designer faces when working with [[complex system]]s and wicked problems, providing tools and techniques which makes it easier for the designer to grasp the complexity of the problem at hand. With a systems-oriented approach towards design, the designer acknowledges that the starting point for the design process is constantly moving, and that "every implemented solution is consequential. It leaves "traces" that cannot be undone." (see Rittel and Webber's 5th property of wicked problems<ref name="Rittel" />).
Designers are well suited to work with complexity and wicked problems for a number of reasons: * They are trained and experienced in creative thinking and idea generation; * They know how to synthesize solutions from complex and fuzzy material; * Designers have an ability to visualize, which is an enormous advantage for understanding and communicating complexity.
S.O.D. emphasizes these abilities as central and seeks to further train the designer in systems thinking and systems practice as a skill and an art.
== Origins == Systems-oriented design builds on systems theory and systems thinking in order to develop practices for addressing complexity in design. Particularly influential is soft systems methodology (SSM), acknowledging conflicting worldviews and people's purposeful actions,<ref>Peter Checkland and John Polter, 2006. ''Learning For Action: A Short Definitive Account of Soft Systems Methodology, and its use Practitioners, Teachers and Students.'' Wiley.</ref> and a systems view on creativity. However, S.O.D. is inspired by critical systems thinking and approaches systems theories in an eclectic way transforming the thoughts of the different theories to fit the design process. The design disciplines build on their own traditions and have a certain way of working with problems, often referred to as ''[[design thinking]]''<ref group="note">The definition of design thinking is not completely agreed upon and the term is used somewhat differently by different people. There is currently considerable academic and business interest in developing further understanding of what design thinking is.</ref><ref>Rowe, G. Peter (1987). Design Thinking. Cambridge: The MIT Press. {{ISBN|978-0-262-68067-7}}.</ref><ref>Tim Brown, 2009. ''Change by Design: How Design Thinking Transforms Organizations and Inspires Innovation''. HarperBusiness. {{ISBN|0-06-176608-9}}</ref><ref>Nigel Cross, 2011. Design Thinking: Understanding How Designers Think and Work. Berg Publishers {{ISBN|1-84788-636-1}}</ref> or ''the design way''.<ref>Harold G. Nelson and Erik Stolterman, 2002. ''The Design Way: Intentional Change in an Unpredictable World : Foundations and Fundamentals of Design Competence''. Educational Technology Pubns {{ISBN|0-87778-305-5}}</ref> Design thinking is a creative process based around the "building up" of ideas. This style of thinking is one of the advantages of the designer and is the reason why simply employing one of the existing systems approach into design, like for example [[systems engineering]], is not found sufficient by the advocates of S.O.D.
Compared with other systems approaches, S.O.D. is less concerned with hierarchies and borders of systems, [[Scientific modelling|modelling]] and [[feedback loops]], and more focused on the whole fields of relations and patterns of interactions. S.O.D. seeks richness rather than simplification of the complex systems.
== Systems thinking in the design process == Important in the systems-oriented [[design process]] is to carry out activities in order to grasp the [[complexity]] of the [[system]] designed for, and to accommodate for a [[Creativity|creative process]] taking place. In order to gain the necessary understanding of the complex system, a comprehensive data capture and analysis phase is needed. [[Visualization (computer graphics)|Visualization]]s play a vital role in the design process, both as a means to analyze and understand the information gathered, and in order to communicate. The obtained insight into the complex system is used to come up with solutions for the design problem.
Methods and techniques from other [[academic discipline|disciplines]] are used in order to understand the complexity of the system, including for example [[Ethnography|ethnographic studies]], [[risk analysis]], and [[Scenario|scenario thinking]]. Methods and concepts unique to S.O.D. include for example the Rich Design Space,<ref>Birger Sevaldson, 2008. ''Rich Design Research Space''. Form Akademisk. http://www.formakademisk.org/index.php/formakademisk/article/view/17</ref> GIGA-mapping,<ref>Birger Sevaldson, 2011. ''GIGA-Mapping: Visualisation for complexity and systems thinking in design''. Paper presented at NORDES 2011, 30 May 2011. http://ocs.sfu.ca/nordes/index.php/nordes/2011/paper/view/409</ref> and Incubation Techniques.
The Rich Design Space includes the physical space of the design studio with sketches, ideas, mood boards, plans etc. and the virtual digital design space of the design software, media like video and sound recording, traditional design techniques and even the social space created in the project. By paying attention to the richness of the design space, the design space can become a very efficient tool to maintain an overview of the complexity of the project all the way.
GIGA-mapping is the central tool for registering, analyzing and managing complexity in S.O.D.. It is used for systematizing and interrelating the information and knowledge obtained.
[[Incubation (psychology)|Incubation]] is one of the 4 proposed stages of [[creativity]]: preparation, incubation, illumination, and verification.<ref>Hadamard, J. (1945). ''The Psychology of Invention in the Mathematical Field''. Princeton University Press</ref> Incubation Techniques are techniques used by the designer in order to acquire the background knowledge needed for an incubation process to take place.
S.O.D. has proved valuable for designers to quickly acquire knowledge of a new domains, and to reveal unexpected parts of a system where a new design can be beneficial.
== Further development and applications == The concept of systems-oriented design was initially proposed by professor [[Birger Ragnvald Sevaldson|Birger Sevaldson]] at [[Oslo School of Architecture and Design|the Oslo School of Architecture and Design (AHO)]] in the context of the [[OCEAN Design Research Association|OCEAN design research network]]. The S.O.D. approach is currently under development through teaching and research projects, as well as through the work of design practitioners. AHO provides Master courses in Systems Oriented Design each term as part of their [[Industrial Design]] program. In these courses, design students are trained in using the tools and techniques of S.O.D. in projects with outside partners. Research projects in systems-oriented design are carried out at the Centre for Design Research<ref>Research related to the topic ''Systems'' carried out at AHO Centre for Design Research: http://www.designresearch.no/themes/systems</ref> at AHO in order to develop the concept, methods and tools further. In 2016 the project Systemic Approach to Architectural Performance<ref>{{cite web|url=https://systemicapproachtoarchitecturalperformance.wordpress.com|title=Systemic Approach to Architectural Performance|author=|date=|website=Systemic Approach to Architectural Performance|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> was announced as an institutional cooperation between the Faculty of Art and Architecture<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fua.tul.cz/en/|title=FUA - FAKULTA UMĚNÍ A ARCHITEKTURY|author=|date=|website=www.fua.tul.cz|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> at the [[Technical University of Liberec]] and the Oslo School of Architecture and Design. Its mission is to link the methodology of systems-oriented design with performance-oriented architecture<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.performanceorienteddesign.net|title=Welcome to the Frontpage|author=|date=|website=www.performanceorienteddesign.net|accessdate=18 April 2018}}</ref> on the case study Marie Davidova's project Wood as a Primary Medium to Architectural Performance. The Oslo-based design consultancy Halogen (www.halogen.no) has used SOD extensively with a varied range of customers. They have suggested a typology of Gigamaps and contributed with other methodological developments. Gigamapping and other SOD methods are used by a growing range of businesses and educational institutions.
== See also == * [[Creative problem-solving#Creative Problem Solving|Creative problem solving process]] * [[Creativity techniques]] * [[Systems thinking]]

{{COI|date=April 2018}} {{EngvarB|date=June 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = ToryBoy The Movie | image = ToryBoy The Movie official release poster.jpg | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[John Walsh (filmmaker)|John Walsh]] | producer = [[Roger James producer|Roger James]] | studio = [[John Walsh (filmmaker)|Walsh Bros Ltd.]] | distributor = [[Fremantle Media]]
[[3DD Productions]] | released = {{film date|df=y|2011|5|11}} | runtime = 100 min. | country = United Kingdom | language = English }} '''''ToryBoy The Movie''''' is a 2011 [[Gonzo journalism|gonzo]]-style British documentary feature film directed by and starring [[John Walsh (filmmaker)|John Walsh]]. It follows Walsh as he becomes a political candidate for the [[Conservative Party (UK)|Conservative Party]] in the north east England constituency of [[Middlesbrough]]. ==Background== A staunch [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour Party]] supporter all his life, Walsh had become disillusioned with the party. When [[David Cameron]] opened the door to allow non party members to run for the Conservative candidacy ahead of the [[United Kingdom general election, 2010|2010 General Election]],{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/politics/conservative/5377839/David-Cameron-to-open-up-candidate-list-to-everyone.html|title=David Cameron to 'open up candidate list to everyone'|author=Chris Irvine|date=24 May 2009|work=Telegraph.co.uk}} John Walsh decided to do just that and document his experiences on camera.[https://youngpeopleinpolitics.org.uk/inspiration/interviews/ John Walsh interview, Young People In Politics, n.d. He came third in the election; Stuart Bell remained the MP of Middlesbrough,{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-13960870|title=Tory Boy takes on Sir Stuart Bell in documentary film|work=BBC News}} but increased the Conservative vote to its highest in thirty years with an 18.8% share of the vote.{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/shared/election2010/results/constituency/c92.stm|title=BBC News - Election 2010 - Constituency - Middlesbrough|work=bbc.co.uk}} ==The film== The film was based on the 72 hours of footage made by Walsh on the campaign trail. It made the case that [[Labour Party (UK)|Labour]]'s [[Stuart Bell]] should not be the [[Member of Parliament]] (MP) of [[Middlesbrough]], as Bell was absent so often from Middlesbrough that he is an unsuitable candidate. Walsh showed the finished film in a free showing a year after the election.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/local-news/toryboy-movie-documentary-up-award-3691723|title=Toryboy The Movie documentary up for award|author=gazettelive Administrator|date=5 August 2011|work=gazettelive}} On the ''Who Can I vote For?'' website a humorous warning is given, "this film contains strong language throughout and scenes of politicians that some viewers may find offensive".{{cite web|url=https://whocanivotefor.co.uk/person/493/john-walsh|title=John Walsh for Member of Parliament for Middlesbrough in the 2010 General Election|website=Who Can I Vote For? by Democracy Club}} [[Mike Amesbury]] appeared in the documentary protesting outside the Conservative conference in Manchester.{{fact|date=November 2017}} Walsh paid homage to the great title designer [[Saul Bass]] and recreated his angular animations to create a fresh approach to telling this story. “This map cap comedy best captured the visual style and the transition of the film was making from a serious expose of the political shenanigans in the North East, to a political satire.”http://www.thewhitebalance.com/work/toryboy-the-movie.html Walsh said that he took a risk making this film in an article with Digital Journal "For something like this, an investigative film, there will be some who think that I have exceeded my brief as a candidate. I would say that it is right to look at injustice and in this country people have died so that we may all have the right to question those in authority and those in public office."http://www.digitaljournal.com/blog/11509 ''[[The Northern Echo]]'' discussed the possible of the film forcing a new by election as a result of its findings. Walsh said he had been serious about becoming an MP and had self-funded his £15,000 election campaign. "When I got to Middlesbrough I found a town that politics had forgotten and a MP who was there in name only, a truly depressingly affair.”http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/9028657.Documentary__could_force_by_election_/ ==Critical reception== The film received positive reviews, with a high score of 8.8 on [[IMDb]]https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1740117/. In 2011 the film was nominated for the [[Grierson Awards]] for "Best Documentary on a Contemporary Theme".http://www.griersontrust.org/grierson-awards/past-awards/2011/the-grierson-awards-2011-shortlist/ http://lfs.org.uk/content/john-walshs-tory-boy-movie-shortlisted-grierson-awards The ''[[Radio Times]]'' film review by Jeremy Aspinall on the film's re-release gave it four stars, and called it "A revealing and droll fly-on-the-wall documentary. It's a fascinating odyssey illuminated by pithily informative animations. Who would have thought politics could be so entertaining?".{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/film/c5xq27/toryboy-the-movie|title=Toryboy the Movie|author=Jeremy Aspinall|work=RadioTimes}} Details of the film's award nomination was covered by the Middlesbrough ''[[Teesside Gazette]]''.https://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/local-news/toryboy-movie-documentary-up-award-3691723 ''[[The Irish Post]]'' Walsh’s “documentary about a rookie Conservative candidate aimed to provide an insight into British political culture, and in doing so uncovered the next big political scandal.” http://irishpost.co.uk/documentary-that-exposed-labour-scandal-back-in-theatres-ahead-of-election/ According to [[Richard Moss]], the [[BBC]]'s North East & Cumbria Political editor, "some silliness aside, it is a thought-provoking insight into the way our political system works or doesn't work on the ground... But I'm not sure he quite nails down a case against Stuart Bell.. And John Walsh doesn't help his case with some of the content in the film." [[Liberal Democratic Party|Liberal Democrat]] commentator Mark Pack wrote on his blog that "John Walsh portrays life on the campaign trail as it really is. It is a hugely enjoyable documentary, which mixes humour, drama and education".{{cite web|url=http://www.markpack.org.uk/29694/toryboy-john-walsh-portrays-life-on-the-campaign-trail-as-it-really-is/|title=ToryBoy: John Walsh portrays life on the campaign trail as it really is|date=1 March 2012|publisher=}} A screening at the [[Frontline Club]] took place on 22 November 2011 followed by a Q&A with John Walsh.{{cite web|url=http://www.frontlineclub.com/toryboy_visits_the_frontline_club/|title=ToryBoy visits the Frontline Club|publisher=}} ''[[Empire (film magazine)|Empire Magazine]]'' gave it three stars and called it a "shit stirring exposé of local politics that will make you cross".[https://www.facebook.com/photo.php?fbid=510147455692929&set=pb.191458757561802.-2207520000.1384175778.&type=3&theater screenshot at Facebook] 20 December 2012{{better source|date=November 2017}} Samuel Scott from review site DVD Compare gave it a B- and wrote "I found this documentary very intriguing and very honest. John is a very likable character, and I wouldn't hesitate in voting for someone with so much passion for a second."[http://dvdcompare.net/review.php?rid=3637 DVD Compare] 14 April 2015 Doc Geeks commented that the film was "a blunt exposé combined with a tinge of lightheartedness. Satirical animation cleverly frames Britain in its political context".[http://docgeeks.com/2011/11/14/review-toryboy-the-movie/ Doc Geeks] November 14th, 2011 On his blog, novelist [[Christopher Fowler]] wrote that ''ToryBoy The Movie'' was "a snapshot of our country’s political apathy in microcosm. It’s heartbreaking to see people blindly supporting their own demise as if they’re playing some kind of long game they’ll probably never live to see the outcome of. Oh, and it’s also very funny."{{cite web|url=http://www.christopherfowler.co.uk/blog/2011/12/02/review-toryboy/|title=Re:View – ‘Toryboy’ - Christopher Fowler|website=www.christopherfowler.co.uk}} When the DVD was released Ben Kamal interviewed Walsh for the Aberdeen student newspaper ''[[Gaudie]]'', and wrote "I was prepared for some careful sneering in the interview and subsequent write-up. This did not (and could not) transpire: firstly because of the film, which comes across as [[Frank Capra]] scripted by [[Evelyn Waugh]]; secondly because of Walsh himself. He is warm, patient and generous, to my own shock I liked him and if you watch the film you'll like him too."[https://issuu.com/gaudie/docs/feb_25] 25 February 2014, p.6 "Dave", a reviewer at the website 60 Minutes With, wrote "''ToryBoy the Movie'' is a fantastic documentary and one in which you will be cheering for John despite what political party you follow. His journey from his Labour roots through to a Tory campaign is superbly documented and will have you both laughing and feeling his frustration in equal measure."[http://60minuteswith.co.uk/reviews/review-toryboy-movie/ 60 Minutes With], 15 November 2016 ''[[The Northern Echo]]'' article by Lucy Richardson she reveals that “at the pre-election hustings, where Sir Stuart does not make an appearance, he tells voters that he will have Sir Stuart jailed before Christmas if elected.”http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/features/9120025.Jolt_from_the_blue/ Two years after the film release, Lord [[Michael Ashcroft]] wrote on his blog: "I’d defy anyone with an interest in politics not to enjoy this film".{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativehome.com/platform/2012/05/lord-ashcroft-two-years-on-a-controversial-film-gives-a-witty-thought-provoking-snapshot-into-the-ge.html|title=Lord Ashcroft: Two years on, a controversial film gives a witty, thought-provoking snapshot into the general election|work=Conservative Home}} He went on to say that "despite the zany tone of the film, it also has a hard-hitting message which questions whether one MP in his safe seat, and perhaps other MPs in similar situations, do enough to justify their salary and expenses."{{cite web|url=http://www.lordashcroft.com/2012/05/two-years-on-a-controversial-film-gives-a-witty-thought-provoking-snapshot-into-the-general-election/|title=Two years on, a controversial film gives a witty, thought-provoking snapshot into the general election - Lord Ashcroft|date=6 May 2012|publisher=}} In April 2017 the political Guido Fawkes website also known as Order Order, ran an article entitled “Inside The Greatest Election Scandal of All Time” says that Walsh “lifted the lid on the real-life world of political campaigning.”https://order-order.com/2017/04/28/inside-greatest-election-scandal-time/ [[Vice (magazine)|Vice Mangazine]]’s Joe Zadeh’s article suggests a link between how Labour in Middlesbrough lost the votes of blue collar people and its shift to the right. He cited ToryBoy The Movie as an example of this shift.https://www.vice.com/en_uk/article/ev445j/how-labour-lost-the-working-class In a podcast interview with BritFlicks Walsh talks about ToryBoy and the difficulties in making the film and also his plans to develop lost [[Ray Harryhausen]] film projects.http://britflicks.com/blog.aspx?blogid=24084http://www.nerdly.co.uk/2018/01/01/interview-john-walsh-tory-boy-the-movie-ray-harryhausen-podcast/ ==Controversy== Although not explicitly inspired by the film, Neil Macfarlane, in a report for local newspaper''[[Teesside Gazette]]'', asked "Are Teessiders getting enough from Sir Stuart Bell?" when he failed to answer over 100 telephone calls made to his constituency office.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/local-news/teessiders-getting-enough-sir-stuart-3693031|title=Are Teessiders getting enough from Sir Stuart Bell?|author=gazettelive Administrator|date=6 September 2011|work=gazettelive}} The ''Gazette'' story was picked up by national newspapers. ''[[The Independent]]'' asked "is Sir Stuart Bell Britain's laziest MP?"Jonathan Brown [https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/politics/no-surgeries-for-14-years--is-sir-stuart-bell-britains-laziest-mp-2350953.html No surgeries for 14 years - is Sir Stuart Bell Britain's laziest MP?], ''Independent'', 7 September 2011Richard Moss [https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-14847291 Middlesbrough MP Sir Stuart Bell fights laziest MP tag], BBC, 9 September 2011 The ''Guardian'' fact-checked the "laziest MP" claim and found that the laziest MP was [[Roger Godsiff]] but the report did confirm that Sir Stuart Bell did not maintain the pivotal role for a MP, an office in their constituency. {{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/politics/reality-check-with-polly-curtis/2011/sep/08/reality-check-britain-s-laziest-mp|title=Reality check: Who are Britain's laziest parliamentarians?|author=Polly Curtis|work=the Guardian|date=8 September 2011}}: "Bell has been an MP for nearly 30 years and has had a distinguished career in parliament as a frontbench spokesman on trade and industry in opposition and the spokesman for the Church of England in the House of Commons and member of the House of Commons commission until last year. He's part of a breed of politicians – also including the Tory [[Edward Leigh]] and Labour's [[Gerald Kaufman]] – who have been extremely active parliamentarians but not always maintained an office in their constituency. One measure of their parliamentary work is the proportion of votes they turn up to." The Labour Party said it would be totally unacceptable if constituents had been unable to contact their MP. [[Ed Miliband]] and the Labour Party expect the highest standards from Labour representatives. It is totally unacceptable if the public cannot reach their MP.{{cite web|url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/news/local-news/labour-launches-probe-middlesbrough-mp-3693109|title=Labour launches probe into Middlesbrough MP|author=gazettelive Administrator|date=8 September 2011|work=gazettelive}} Sir Stuart Bell did have a right of reply, which appeared in the short film ''ToryBoy The AfterMath''.{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativehome.com/platform/2014/05/john-walsh-toryboy-the-aftermath-or-the-town-that-politics-forgot.html|title=John Walsh: ToryBoy – the aftermath (or: the Town That Politics Forgot…)|work=Conservative Home}} The film's expose nearly forced a By Election.{{cite web|url=http://www.thenorthernecho.co.uk/news/9028657.Documentary__could_force_by_election_/|title=Documentary 'could force by-election'|work=The Northern Echo}} The film's re-release in 2015 caused more controversy after a showing in Middlesbrough by [[Teesside University]] was cancelled to avoid breaching union rules on political neutrality in the run up to the general election. According to Walsh's interview with ''[[Teesside Gazette]]''https://www.questia.com/newspaper/1G1-408518499/director-upset-as-toryboy-film-screening-cancelled the film was booked in by the Student Union, but at the last minute the screening was halted.{{cite web|url=http://www.conservativehome.com/platform/2015/04/john-walsh-toryboy-the-move-banned-in-middlesbrough.html|title=ToryBoy The Movie – banned in Middlesbrough|author=John Walsh|work=Conservative Home|date=April 2015}}Matthew Brown [http://mmj.tees.ac.uk/~project22/index5d95.html?p=863 Student Union involved in row over planned screening of controversial Toryboy the Movie], ''[[The North Crowd]]'' 27 April 2015 "I think it's a shame really," said Walsh. "It's a unique opportunity for students to hold me to account."https://www.questia.com/newspaper/1G1-408518499/director-upset-as-toryboy-film-screening-cancelled Teesside Free Education Campaign activists, writing on the website of the [[National Campaign Against Fees and Cuts]], mentioned the union cancelling the film: "A few weeks after the student elections, a planned screening of the film Tory Boy, made by the 2010 Tory candidate for Middlesbrough about his experience standing in the area was cancelled, despite having been screened at schools and colleges up and down the country without controversy." Teesside Free Education activists [http://anticuts.com/2015/09/21/our-year-with-the-worst-union-in-the-country/ Our year with the ‘worst union in the country’] ''Anticuts.com'' September 21, 2015 The [[North Crowd]] featured an interview with John Walsh website where they showed the actual print work that was created by the Student Union.https://mmj.tees.ac.uk//~project22/index5d95.html?p=863 ==Re-releases== The film received a re-release in cinemas in 2015 in the lead up to the [[2015 UK General Election]].{{cite web|url=http://www.irishpost.co.uk/entertainment/documentary-that-exposed-labour-scandal-back-in-theatres-ahead-of-election|title=Satirical film ToryBoy The Movie returns to big screen|work=The Irish Post}}{{cite web|url=http://www.newsshopper.co.uk/news/11807584.BAFTA_nominated_Greenwich_filmmaker_s_controversial_ToryBoy_returns_to_cinemas_before_election/|title=BAFTA-nominated Greenwich filmmaker's controversial ToryBoy returns to cinemas before election|work=News Shopper}} Community cinema screenings were given and included a Q&A from Walsh. http://hithergreencinema.com/2014/05/a-little-bit-of-politics-tory-boy-the-movie-plus-director-john-walsh-and-qa-with-your-local-candidates/ After a digital download version of the film was made available during the [[United Kingdom General Election, 2017]].[https://order-order.com/2017/04/28/inside-greatest-election-scandal-time/ "Inside The Greatest Election Scandal of all time."], [[Guido Fawkes]], 28 April 2017 == Soundtrack == The film used older film ques from films across the last six decades to create a unique soundscape. ''[[Radio Times]]'' described it as "a fascinating odyssey illuminated by pithily informative animations and music from films like ''[[It's a Mad, Mad, Mad, Mad World]]'' and ''[[Midnight Cowboy]]''."{{cite web|url=http://www.radiotimes.com/film/c5xq27/toryboy-the-movie/|title=Toryboy the Movie – review - cast and crew, movie star rating and where to watch film on TV and online|website=Radio Times}}. Other notable films which provided musical material included: ''[[King Kong (1976 film)|King Kong]]'', ''[[The Firm (1993 film)|The Firm]]'' and ''[[The Ladykillers]]''.{{fact|date=November 2017}} ==Home media== ''ToryBoy The Movie'' was issued for the first time on [[DVD]] 1 October 2012 by [[FremantleMedia]]. It included extras on the making of the film and gave Stuart Bell a right of reply, where he denied the allegations levelled against him in the film.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-england-tees-19936270|title=Middlesbrough MP Stuart Bell dies|date=13 October 2012|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} The film was also made available as a high definition download on [[Vimeo]] {{cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/ondemand/toryboythemovie|title=Watch ToryBoy The Movie Online - Vimeo On Demand|first=|last=walshbros|date=4 December 2016|publisher=|via=Vimeo}} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.toryboythemovie.com/ Tory Boy the Movie official Website] * {{IMDb title|1740117|title=Toryboy the Movie}} * [http://film.britishcouncil.org/toryboy-the-movie/ ToryBoy The Movie [[British Council]] Listing] [[Category:Films directed by John Walsh]] [[Category:Documentary films about politics]] [[Category:Documentaries about politics]] [[Category:Documentary films about politicians]] [[Category:Films about elections]] [[Category:Biographical films about politicians]] [[Category:2011 films]] [[Category:2010s documentary films]] [[Category:British documentary films]] [[Category:British films]] [[Category:British independent films]] [[Category:United Kingdom general election, 2010]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Documentary films about elections]] [[Category:Documentary films about the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Political satire]] [[Category:Satire]] [[Category:The arts and politics]] [[Category:2010s political films| Satire]] [[Category:British political films]] [[Category:British satirical films]] [[Category:2010 in British politics]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Thomism}} '''''Treatise on Law''''' is [[St. Thomas Aquinas]]' major work of [[philosophy of law|legal philosophy]]. It forms questions 90–108 of the ''Prima Secundæ'' ("First [Part] of the Second [Part]") of the [[Summa Theologica|''Summa Theologiæ'']],[http://www.utm.edu/staff/jfieser/vita/research/aqu.htm THE LOGIC OF NATURAL LAW IN AQUINAS'S "TREATISE ON LAW"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131016223414/http://www.utm.edu/staff/jfieser/vita/research/aqu.htm |date=2013-10-16 }}
James Fieser
Journal of Philosophical Research, 1992, Vol. 17, pp. 147–164.
accessed Dec-17-2013 Aquinas' masterwork of [[scholasticism|Scholastic]] [[philosophical theology]]. Along with [[Aristotle|Aristotelianism]], it forms the basis for the legal theory of [[canon law (Catholic Church)|Catholic canon law]].[[Dr. Edward N. Peters]], [http://canonlaw.info/ CanonLaw.info] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928005444/http://www.canonlaw.info/ |date=2011-09-28 }}, accessed Dec-17-2013 ==Aquinas' notion of law== Aquinas defines a law as "an ordinance of reason for the common good, made by him who has care of the community, and promulgated."Gateway Edition, pg. ix Law is an ordinance of reason because it must be reasonableLaw of Christ I, pg. 236 or based in reason and not merely in the will of the legislator.J. Budziszewski, [http://www.undergroundthomist.org/sites/default/files/related-documents/1-2Q90Art1.pdf ''Commentary on Treatise on Law''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219121116/http://www.undergroundthomist.org/sites/default/files/related-documents/1-2Q90Art1.pdf |date=2013-12-19 }}, accessed Dec-19-2013Gateway Edition, pg. 2 (''Summa,'' Ia–IIæ, Q.90, A.1, Obj.3) It is for the common good because the end or ''[[Telos (philosophy)|telos]]'' of law is the good of the community it binds, and not merely the good of the lawmaker or a special interest group. It is made by the proper authority who has "care of the community", and not arbitrarily imposed by outsiders. It is promulgated so that the law can be known. He says: {{quote|Thus from the four preceding articles [of Question 90], the definition of law may be gathered; and it is nothing else than an ordinance of reason for the common good, made by him who has care of the community, and promulgated.{{cite web |url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Treatise_on_Law |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-12-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219002500/https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Treatise_on_Law |archivedate=2013-12-19 |df= }}, accessed Dec-19-2013}} Strictly speaking, this is a definition of human law.Gateway Edition, pg. viii The term "law" as used by Aquinas is [[Equivocal predication|equivocal]], meaning that the primary meaning of law is "human law", but other, analogous concepts are expressed with the same term.Gateway Edition, pg. x ==Kinds of law== ===Natural law=== [[Natural law]] or the law of nature refers to normative properties that are inherent by virtue of human nature and universally cognizable through human reason. Historically, natural law refers to the use of reason to analyze both social and personal human nature to deduce binding rules of moral behavior. The law of nature, being determined by nature, is universal. In the Treatise on Law, deals with Aquinas view’s on the objective ethical aspect of human decision-making. Aquinas presents a question and then puts each question into article raising specific questions he has. The first three questions are broken down in four topics what is the essence of law, the effects of law, and the eternal law. The first question Ninety of Aquinas Treatise on Law is what is the essence of law? In the first question he breakdowns the question into four articles. The first article is Does Law Belong to Reason? Aquinas believes that reason is the first thing human acts upon. “And the source in any kind of thing is the measure and rule of that kind of thing…and so we conclude that law belongs to reason.” (90.1) The second is Law Always Ordained for the Common Good? We cannot find common good without reason; it guides us to common happiness through law. Happiness for the whole community. The third article is Any Person’s Reason Competent to Make Law? And the last article is Promulgation an Essential Component of Law? Promulgation is important so that the law can achieve force. By the end of the fourth article Aquinas comes up with his definition on Law, “Law is an ordination of reason for the common good by one who has care for the community, and promulgated.”(90.4) Next we Next is question is Ninety-One on what are the different kinds of law? Aquinas establishes four types of laws eternal law, natural law, human law, and divine law. Eternal law “Gods providence rules the world…his reason evidently governs the entire community in the universe.” (91.1) Aquinas believes that eternal law is all gods doing. Natural law is the participation in the eternal law by rational creators. Natural law allows us to decide between good and evil. Next we have Human Law; particular applications of law resulting by reason. “Human law originally sprang from nature.” (91.3) The last law is Divine this law is important because “it belongs to any law to be directed to the common good at its end.” (91.4) Theses laws all go together and the relationship must be presented to comprehend them individually. Question 92 is the Effects on Laws. The first article is the Effect of Law to Make Human Beings Good? Aquinas feels in order for law to make people good that law needs to guide people to their right virtue. “Therefore, since virtue makes those possessing it good, the proper effect of law is consequently to make its subject good, either absolutely or in some respect.” (92.1) The second article of 92 is Do we Suitably Designate Legal Acts? This article focuses on what “designate legal acts consist of “commanding, forbidding, permitting, and punishing.” (92.2) Aquinas believes that some human acts are good and some are evil. Question 93 focuses on the Eternal as a whole. Aquinas is asking is the eternal law the supreme plan in god? Aquinas argues whether or not if the eternal law is a plan of god. He says “God made each thing with its own nature. Therefore, the eternal law is not the same as divine plan.” (93.1) Augustine contradicts this idea by stating “the eternal law is the supreme plan that we should always obey.” (93.1) Aquinas believes that the eternal law “is simply the plan of divine wisdom that directs all the actions and movements of created things.” (93.1) He saying that god is above all else. That he creates everything in the universe. Human beings participate in eternal law in two ways by action and cognition. “The virtuous are completely subjects to the eternal law, as they always act in accord with.” (93.6) Aquinas believes people who are truthful act according to the eternal law. ===Human law=== {{see also|Determinatio}} For Aquinas, human law is only valid if it conforms to natural law. If a law is unjust, then it is not actually a law, but a "perversion of law".[http://www.newadvent.org/summa/2095.htm Summa I–II, q95, a2, 'dicendum quod''] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111109214550/http://newadvent.org/summa/2095.htm |date=2011-11-09 }}Internet Encyclopedia of Philosophy, [http://www.iep.utm.edu/natlaw/#H1 "Natural Law"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170316052718/http://www.iep.utm.edu/natlaw/ |date=2017-03-16 }}, accessed Dec-20-2013 ==Layout== [[File:SummaTheologiae.jpg|thumb|right|''Summa theologica'', Pars secunda, prima pars. (copy by Peter Schöffer, 1471)]] The ''Treatise on Law'' (as part of the Summa Theologica) is divided into Articles (or broad topics) and Questions (or specific topics). The Questions each argue for a single thesis and defend it against objections. The division is as follows:{{cite web |url=https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Treatise_on_Law |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-12-18 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131219002500/https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Treatise_on_Law |archivedate=2013-12-19 |df= }}, accessed Dec-17-2013 '''1. IN GENERAL''' :Q. 90: Of the Essence of Law (the rationality, end, cause, and promulgation of law) :Q. 91: Of the Various Kinds of Law (eternal, natural, human, divine, sin laws) :Q. 92: Of the Effects of Law '''2. IN PARTICULAR''' :Q. 93: Of the Eternal Law :Q. 94: Of the Natural Law :Q. 95: Of Human Law :Q. 96: Of the Power of Human Law :Q. 97: Of Change in Laws :Q. 98: Of the Old Law :Q. 99: Of the Precepts of the Old Law :Q. 100: Of the Moral Precepts of the Old Law :Q. 101: Of the Ceremonial Precepts in Themselves :Q. 102: Of the Causes of the Ceremonial Precepts :Q. 103: Of the Duration of the Ceremonial Precepts :Q. 104: Of the Judicial Precepts :Q. 105: Of the Reason for the Judicial Precepts :Q. 106: Of the Law of the Gospel, Called the New Law, Considered in Itself :Q. 107: Of the New Law as Compared with the Old :Q. 108: Of Those Things That Are Contained in the New Law ==Criticism== William S. Brewbacker III has called it "perhaps the most famous of [[Metaphysics|metaphysical]] legal texts”,Brewbaker, Metaphysics of Law, 575. while Robert M. Hutchins declared it “that greatest of all books on the [[philosophy of law]]”.Hutchins, World State, 38. ==See also== *[[St. Thomas Aquinas]] *[[Summa Theologica]] *[[Philosophy of law]] *''[[Determinatio]]'' *[[Canon law (Catholic Church)]] *[[Christian views on the Old Covenant]] ==References== {{reflist|2}} ===Bibliography=== *Aquinas, St. Thomas. ''Treatise on Law (''Summa Theologica, ''Questions 90–97): With a New Introduction by Ralph McInerny, University of Notre Dame''. (Washington, D.C.: Gateway Editions, Regnery Publishing, Inc. ©1956; 2001 printing). *Brewbaker, William S., III. ''Thomas Aquinas and the Metaphysics of Law'' (Alabama Law Review, Vol. 58 [2007], pg. 575); U of Alabama Public Law Research Paper No. 898941; Social Science Research Network: http://ssrn.com/abstract=898941. Accessed 28 March 2016. *[[Bernhard Häring|Häring, Bernard, C.SS.R.]] ''The Law of Christ, Vol. I''. Translated by Edwin G. Kaiser, C.PP.S. (Westminster, Maryland: The Newman Press ©1961, Second Printing November 1961). *Hutchins, Robert M. ''Aquinas Lecture 1949: St. Thomas and the World State'' (Milwaukee: Marquette University Press, 1949). {{Thomas Aquinas}} [[Category:Philosophy of law]] [[Category:Medieval philosophical literature]] [[Category:Scholasticism]] [[Category:13th-century Christian texts]] [[Category:13th-century books]] [[Category:Christian theology books]] [[Category:Works by Thomas Aquinas]]

{{Refimprove|date=December 2007}} '''Tutima Uhrenfabrik GmbH Ndl. Glashütte''' is a [[List of German watch manufacturers|German]] [[watchmaker]] established in 1927 in [[Glashütte]], [[Saxony]].
Their products include [[Analog watch|analog]] [[chronograph]]s of high precision, including pilot's watches (''Fliegerchronograph''), which are standard [[military equipment]] of [[NATO]] and [[Luftwaffe]] pilots.{{fact|date=September 2018}}
Tutima has four [[Product lining|product lines]] made in Glashütte: Saxon One, M2, Grand Flieger, and Patria.
Tutima Germany is registered with HRB 140173 at Amtsgericht Delmenhorst and is a member of Industrie und Handelskammer Oldenburg. The [[brand]] Tutima has been registered since 7 April 1970.<ref>Deutsches Patentamt, No. 867903</ref> Tutima USA, Inc., an independent company, is based in [[Torrance, California]].
==See also== *[[List of German watch manufacturers]] *[[Glash%C3%BCtte Original]]

page.title: William Blake's Illustrations of the Book of Job

revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:William Blake's ''Illustrations of the Book of Job''}} [[File:Blake Job Evil Dreams Detail bb421 1 13-12 ps 300.jpg|thumb|300px|Plate 11 of the engravings, detail of centre image.]] '''[[William Blake]]'s ''Illustrations of the Book of Job''''' primarily refers to a series of twenty-two [[engraving|engraved]] prints (published 1826) by Blake illustrating the biblical [[Book of Job]]. It also refers to two earlier sets of watercolours by Blake on the same subject (1806 and 1821). The engraved ''Illustrations'' are considered to be Blake's greatest masterpieces in the medium of engraving,Schoenherr 1997, p. 41Essick 1980, p. 234 and were also a rare commercial and critical success for Blake. ==Development and printing history== [[File:Blake 1793 Job's Tormentors.jpg|thumb|Blake's 1793 engraving for The Book of Job. This engraving, although not included in the 1826 ''Illustrations'', most closely resembles the tenth illustration, ''Job Rebuked by his Friends''.]] ===Origins=== As early as 1785 Blake had sketched several ink studies of an illustration to Job.[http://www.blakearchive.org/exist/blake/archive/work.xq?workid=but551&java=yes The William Blake archive][http://www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ViewWork?cgroupid=999999961&workid=1138&searchid=8884 One of the ink drawings] in the collection of the [[Tate gallery]]. In 1793 Blake engraved a composition based upon these drawings, which he offered for sale in the ''Prospectus to the Public'' for twelve shillings.Erdman 1988, pp. 692–3 This, alongside an engraving of [[Ezekiel]], are the only extant examples of an intended series of biblical illustrations that were never completed. Blake reworked the Job plate sometime after 1804, but the resulting print was not included in the ''Illustrations''. Blake's next illustration was the tempera painting ''Job and his Daughters'' (1800), commissioned by Thomas Butts (see gallery below).[http://www.nga.gov/fcgi-bin/tinfo_f?object=30221 The painting], in the collection of [[The National Gallery of Art]]. This has similarities to plate 20 of the engraved illustrations, but it is unclear whether the print was directly based upon it.Schoenherr 1997, p. 43 ===The watercolours=== The engraved illustrations to Job originated as a series of [[watercolor|watercolour]]s that Blake painted in 1805-6, also for Butts. These 19 watercolours are referred to as the ''Butts Set'' (in the collection of the [[Morgan Library & Museum]]). A second set of watercolours, known as the ''Linell Set'' (mostly in the collection of the [[Fogg Art Museum]]) was produced in 1821 at the request of [[John Linnell (painter)|John Linell]]. Linell traced the watercolours from the "Butts set"; these tracings were then coloured in by Blake. As a result of this unusual process, the outlines of the ''Linell set'' are thicker and the colouring is uniformly darker, with a more restricted palette than the ''Butts set''. Blake also added two new designs to the ''Linell set'', and added copies of these to the Butts set. The two designs added were No.s 17 and 20, ''The Vision of Christ'' and ''Job and His Daughters''. There is also another set of watercolours known as the ''New Zealand Set''. These were initially believed to be from Blake's hand, but their authenticity has been all but refuted by scholars such as [[Martin Butlin]]Butlin 1981, pp. 409-10 and Bo Lindberg.Paley, Morton D. (Nov. 1987) Untitled review in ''The Burlington Magazine'', Vol. 129, No. 1016 , pp. 747-748 They are most likely copies after the engravings by someone in the circle of John Linell, as they have no unique features. Image:Job's Evil Dreams-butts.jpg|''Job's Evil Dreams'', from the Butts set, 1805-6. Image:Job's Evil Dreams-Linell.jpg|''Job's Evil Dreams'', from the Linell set, 1821. ===The engravings=== [[File:Job's Evil Dreams.jpg|thumb|upright|Plate 11, showing the marginal glosses. The line directly above the centre image reads: ''Satan himself is transformed into an Angel of Light & his Ministers into Ministers of Righteousness'']] In 1823 Linell formally commissioned Blake to engrave plates for printing. Unlike Blake's own productions in [[relief etching]], this, like other commissioned work, was produced using the [[Intaglio (printmaking)|intaglio]] method of engraving. However, Blake rejected the "mixed method" popular among commercial reproductive engravers of his time. The "mixed method" entailed lightly [[etching]] guidelines into the plate. The image was then engraved by the dot and lozenge method and by [[stipple engraving|stippling]]. Instead, Blake engraved his illustrations in pure line and without preliminary etching. The engravings were completed in 1825, and an edition of 315 was produced in 1826. These were the last set of illustrations that Blake would complete. His illustrations of Dante's ''[[Divine Comedy]]'' were left unfinished upon his death. The completed engravings differ from Blake's original watercolours mainly in the complex marginal designs that they employ. These comment upon the text with biblical quotes and paraphrases, and also contain images that reinforce the themes of the main illustrations. After completing the engravings, Blake painted an additional tempera of ''Satan Smiting Job with Boils'' in 1826.[http://www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ViewWork?cgroupid=999999961&workid=1093&searchid=8903&tabview=text The Painting on the website of the Tate] ==Analysis== The ''Book of Job'' was an important influence upon Blake's writings and art;Schoenherr 1997, p. 42 Blake apparently identified with Job, as he spent his lifetime unrecognized and impoverished. [[Harold Bloom]] has interpreted Blake's most famous lyric, ''[[The Tyger]]'', as a revision of God's rhetorical questions in the Book of Job concerning Behemoth and Leviathan.Bloom 2006, p. 17 Blake also depicted the story of Job throughout his career as an artist. The song of Enion in Night the Second of ''[[Vala, or The Four Zoas|The Four Zoas]]'' also demonstrates that Blake identified with Job.{{cite book | last = Bloom | first = | title = footnote | publisher = | date = 1988 | location = | pages = 954 | url = | doi = | id = | quote = This biblical lyric echoes Job 28:12-13 in its very powerful lines 35:11-13...It is difficult not to think of Blake himself in lines 35:11-15.| isbn = }} These lines read:
What is the price of Experience do men buy it for a song
Or wisdom for a dance in the street? No it is bought with the price
Of all that a man hath his house his wife his children
Wisdom is sold in the desolate market where none come to buy
And in the witherd field where the farmer plows for bread in vain
Damon 1966, p. 32 ===Symbolism=== Blake used symbols extensively in the illustrations; most notable is the use of right and left limbs in the figures.[http://www.tate.org.uk/servlet/ViewWork?cgroupid=999999961&workid=1048&searchid=8884&tabview=text Analysis] of ''Job's Sons and Daughters Overwhelmed by Satan'' from the website of the [[Tate gallery]].Damon 1966, p. 3. Damon attributes the origin of this observation to Joseph Wickstead's ''Blake's Vision of the Book of Job'', 1924. The right limb represents the spiritual and the good; the left, the material and evil. In plate six, [[Satan]] smites Job with boils using his left hand, and in plate 15 God indicates Behemoth and Leviathan with his left hand. Contrarily, God banishes Satan with his right hand in plate sixteen and speaks to Job from the whirlwind in plate fourteen with his right foot extended forward. Some scholars, however, have asserted that this systematic interpretation fails to account for inconsistencies in such symbolism and is excessively subjective.[[W.J.T. Mitchell|Mitchell, W.J.T.]] "Blake's Composite Art" in ''William Blake'' from Bloom's BioCritiques, ed [[Harold Bloom]]. Chelsea House Publishers, 2006. p. 149 The Hebrew incorporated in the Butts watercolor ''Job's Evil Dreams'' and in the engravings ''title'' plate and plate numbered 2 ''Hast thou considered my Servant Job'' is analyzed in 'Blake's Hebrew Calligraphy.' Abraham Samuel Shiff "Blake's Hebrew Calligraphy" ''Blake An Illustrated Quarterly'', vol. 46, no. 2 (Fall 2012)[http://blake.lib.rochester.edu/blakeojs/index.php/blake/article/view/shiff462] The theme of an Orthodox Jewish ritual used in the composition of plate numbered 17 ''I have heard thee with the hearing of the Ear but now my Eye seeth thee'' is explained in 'Blake's Priestly Blessing: God Blesses Job.' Abraham Samuel Shiff "Blake's Priestly Blessing: God Blesses Job" ''Blake An Illustrated Quarterly'', vol. 47, no. 3 (winter 2013-14)[http://blake.lib.rochester.edu/blakeojs/index.php/blake/article/view/shiff473/shiff473] ===Artistic influences=== [[File:Behemoth.jpg|thumb|Detail of watercolour illustrating [[Behemoth]] and [[Leviathan]], upon which plate 15 of the engravings was based.]] From early in his artistic career, Blake collected the prints of [[Albrecht Dürer]]. The depiction of Behemoth in plate 15 of the engravings is believed to have been influenced by ''[[Dürer's Rhinoceros]]''.Essick 1980, p. 245 In his ''Public Address'' (possibly from 1810[http://www.blakearchive.org/blake/erdman.html Electronic version of Erdman's ''Complete Poetry and Prose''], click '''textual notes''' and then '''Public Address''' for information.), Blake also indicates "Marc Antonio" ([[Marcantonio Raimondi]]), as an artist who inspired his linear technique of engraving.[http://www.english.uga.edu/nhilton/Blake/blaketxt1/public_address.html Ibid.] posted on the University of Georgia's website "Julio Romano" ([[Giulio Romano]]), [[Raphael]], and [[Michelangelo]] are also mentioned by Blake in this address. ==Critical reception and legacy== Of the edition of 315, only 20 copies of the illustrations were sold in Blake's lifetime, mostly to people within Blake's [[Ancients (art group)|immediate circle]] (such as [[Samuel Palmer]]). However, the ''Illustrations'' brought Blake an unprecedented degree of recognition. The [[Royal Academy]] and the [[King's Library]] each bought a copy; the former also awarded Blake £25. Such notables as [[John Constable]] and [[Lady Caroline Lamb]] invited him to dine, and the collector Charles Alders introduced him to [[Samuel Taylor Coleridge]].[https://books.google.com/books?id=yel1AU0YlGsC&printsec=frontcover&client=safari#PPA33,M1 ''The Cambridge Companion to William Blake''], on Google Books. The ''Illustrations'' also gained critical acknowledgment after Blake's death more quickly than his [[William Blake's prophetic books|prophetic books]]. As early as 1857 [[John Ruskin]] wrote of Blake in ''The Elements of Drawing'' that
The ''Book of Job'', engraved by himself, is of the highest rank in certain characters of imagination and expression; in the mode of obtaining certain effects of light it will also prove a very useful example to you. In expressing conditions of glaring and flickering light, Blake is greater than Rembrandt.[https://books.google.com/books?id=nEg8ULbzEJcC&pg=PA223&dq=Blake+is+greater+than+rembrandt#PPA223,M1 ''The Elements of Drawing'' in ''The Works of John Ruskin'', ed. Edward Tyas Cook, on Google Books]
The triple-mirror design in the background of plate 20, ''Job and his Daughters'', is believed to have influenced [[William Holman Hunt]]'s use of the same motif in his painting ''The Lady of Shalott''; Blake was highly regarded by the [[Pre-Raphaelites]]. [[Ralph Vaughan Williams]] based his ballet ''[[Job: A Masque for Dancing]]'' (first staged in 1931) upon the ''Illustrations''. Image:HuntShallotlarge.jpg|''The Lady of Shalott'', 1905. Image:Job and His Daughters(tempera).jpg|''Job and His Daughters'', 1800. Image:Book of Job Plate 20.jpg|Plate 20 of the engravings. ==Table of Illustrations== Blake did not give titles to the illustrations and the most prominent text in the margins is used by some scholars (such as [[S. Foster Damon]]) as a title for a given illustration. Others, such as Robert Essick, use descriptive titles.The titles based upon biblical verses are from Foster's ''Blake's Job'', and the descriptive titles are from the [http://www.blakearchive.org/exist/blake/archive/copy.xq?copyid=bb421.1&java=yes William Blake Archive] Therefore, both are given here. In some cases the titles are the same. Note that Blake's marginal texts are paraphrases of biblical passages and so will not be exactly identical to the linked verse. {| class="unsortable wikitable" style="margin-left:0.5em; text-align:center" ! Butts set !! Linell set !! Engraving !! Descriptive title !! Textual title with
corresponding chapter and verse!! Related works
